24 . A resolution is also a statutory measure available to members and ministers to raise discussions in the House on a matter of common interest .
Unlike ordinary motions resolutions are provided in the Rules of Procedure of both the Houses.
The House adopts a motion or resolution adopted by the House declares its opinion on the subject and becomes an order of the House .
As far as their influence is concerned resolutions passed by Parliament fall in these categories :
Such resolutions are not binding on the government in which the House has expressed its opinion only .
The practice is that in these resolutions it is wholly dependent on the discretion of the government to give effect or not give effect to the views expressed .
The resolutions passed by the House in matters of its own proceedings are binding and they exercise the power of law .
Their validity cannot be challenged in courts .
Resolutions which have a statutory effect if accepted are binding on the government and have the power of law .
Should that resolution be considered a censure against the government ?
However after the leave of the House if the member wants to withdraw his proposal he can do so only with the permission of the House .
Notice of no - confidence motion can also be withdrawn by all the members who have signed the notice of the motion and should be taken before the item is moved in the House .
In that case the item in the House is not mentioned or brought before the House .
Rajya Sabha is not empowered to consider a no - confidence motion because under the Constitution the Government is collectively elected to the Lok Sabha alone .
A censure motion is different from a no - confidence motion .
The motion of no - confidence does not mention the reasons on which it is based but it is necessary to mention such causes or charges in the censure motion and it is offered for specific purpose to निंदा the government for certain policies and actions .
A motion is moved against the Council of Ministers or against a minister or against some ministers or in opposition to some of them or in opposition to any policy which appears to be खेद by the House .
The motion should be specific and self - explanatory so as to record the reasons for censure precisely .
Whether the motion is in order or not for some reason it is final .
No leave is required to move a censure motion .

Rules committee : Each House has a Rules Committee .
In Lok Sabha Rules are 15 members of the Committee including the Speaker who is the ex officio Chairman of the Committee .
In the Rajya Sabha the Chairman and the Deputy Chairman are 16 members of the committee .
Suggestions for amendments or additions to the Rules can be made by any member of the House either by a Minister or by the Committee himself .
Thus the Committee is competent to take the form of a " लेने or Public Grievances Committee .
Privilege committee : Members of each House of Parliament individually and collectively receive some privileges from which they are entitled to certain rights and privileges without which the House and its members cannot effectively and function .
When a question of breach of privilege arises even though the House is competent to deal with it the Committee of Privileges is referred to it for general scrutiny and reporting .
The Privilege Committee is usually constituted by their Presiding Officers in both the Houses .
It has 15 members in the Lok Sabha and 10 members in the Rajya Sabha .
The functions of the Committee are of the semi - judicial nature and have wide powers .
Though its findings are subject to the ultimate decision of the House it enjoys the confidence of the House and its recommendations are seldom rejected .
The Committee plays an important role in safeguarding the powers and prestige of Parliament and Parliament .

The Committee on Papers Laid on the Table : At every session the Government puts before the Parliament its statements statements statements statements statements statements statements statements statements statements statements statements statements statements statements statements and reports to inform members on various matters .

The Committee has 15 members in the Lok Sabha and 10 members in the Rajya Sabha .

His President is the President ; in him all executive powers are vested and exercised by his name .

But it is recognised that unlike the US President our President is only a nominal or constitutional head of the executive .
On the contrary the United States ' s Presidential Rule is a separation of powers and the President is the chief executive for a fixed term and cannot be dismissed often .
In the U. S. system the President chooses his ministers from among the common citizens and the ministers are not members of the Legislature whereas in the parliamentary system ministers are drawn from Parliament and they are responsible for the Lok Sabha .
It may be said that in the parliamentary system emphasis is laid on the concept of executive responsibility while in the Presidential system the stability of the executive is evidently more important .
But it is wrong to say that we have completely adopted the British parliamentary system .

Where India was the old name and it represented the first expression of the consciousness of unity and integrity of the country " India was the modern name which had the country known all over the world .

India is a " Union ; it was intended to emphasise the fact that it was not the result of bargaining or agreement between the constituent units but a clear declaration of power and authority to India .
No State could therefore secede from the Union nor could it suo की vary its territory as laid down in the First Schedule to the Constitution .
Article 2 provides that Parliament shall by law admit or establish new States in the Union of India on such terms and conditions as it deems fit .
The latest state in the Union was extended by सिक्किम and सिक्किम Constitutional amendments in 1974 and 1975 .
This was done by the people of Sikkim at the request of the Sikkim Assembly and by the plebiscite .
Under article 3 Parliament has the power to form a new state by separating its territory from any State or by uniting two or more States or parts or by uniting any territory with the part of a state .
It can increase or decrease the area of a state and even alter the boundaries or name of a state .
Thus the State has no guarantee of territorial integrity or its existence .
But at the same time it has been held that the Parliament ' s power to diminish the area of a state does not include the power to dedicate the Indian territory to a foreign state .
( Regulations of the Union and बस्तियों in relation to बस्तियों ) AIR 1950 SC विनियम ) .
It can therefore be said that India is an indestructible Union of mortal states .
It represents that a person has a complete political membership of the state : he has a permanent allegiance to the state and that he has been duly accepted by the state in the political system .
Citizenship provides certain rights , duties and privileges .
All public offices are open to citizens .
The right to vote and certain fundamental rights are accessible to citizens and citizens like paying taxes defending the nation etc .
Citizenship can also be viewed as a legal relationship between the individual and the state under which the individual pledges his loyalty to the state and gives protection to the individual .
This relationship is regulated by national law and recognized by international law .
On 26 November 1949 the Constituent Assembly adopted the Constitution and applied immediately articles 5 to 9 relating to citizenship .
Till then those of us who lived in British India were subject to the Crown and thus British subjects .
The partition of India and the migration of large numbers created enormous problems for determining citizenship .
Citizenship provisions in the Constitution - articles 5 to 11 - gave the Constitution Drafting Committee the worst of all and took more than two years to prepare and make it final .
However the Constitution laid down the law only in respect of who would be the citizen of India at the time of the commencement of the Constitution .
It did not provide for the acquisition and termination of citizenship .
Article 11 said that Parliament could regulate the right of citizenship by law .
Under article 5 - 8 each person who was named after him was a citizen of India born in India ; but not more than one of the six months since the commencement of the Constitution were born in India .
Thus at the time of the commencement of the Constitution ( e ) for citizenship ( i . e . on the basis of domicile ) came from Pakistan and provided for citizenship for Indians residing abroad .
Domicile is an important criterion for citizenship of a country .
Raza v. State of Bombay AIR 1966 SC 1966 .
Article 5 provides that if a person lives in the territory of India on the commencement of the Constitution ( अधिवास ) of the Constitution ( i . e . a person less than five in India ordinarily .
A person can alter the aforesaid domicile on the basis of birth or residence .
In fact citizenship denoted by domicile and not vice - versa.
The domicile is different from citizenship because it is mainly concerned with the state area and not membership of the community which is at the root of the principle of citizenship ( Abdul Rehman Rehman v. State of Bombay AIR 1964 .
It provides single citizenship and relates to domicile in the territory of the whole of India and not vice - versa.
Unlike the United States there is no separate State citizenship in India .
His domicile is only one domicile that is domicile in the territory of India .
( Pradeep Jain v. Union of India AIR 1984 SC 654 ) .
A person migrating from Pakistan : Article 6 provides for citizenship rights of migrants from Pakistan before the commencement of the Constitution .
There are two types of distinctions among such migrants viz. those migrating to India before July 19 1948 when the permit system for migration was introduced on July 19 1948 and those who came after that date .
A person who had migrated from Pakistan before July 19 1948 and settled in India shall be deemed to be a citizen of India at the commencement of the Constitution if any of his parents were born in India in general or in India .
Thus the future citizenship needs of all Indians residing abroad have been considered .
Voluntary acquisition of citizenship of another country Article 9 provides that if a person has voluntarily acquired the citizenship of a foreign state his right to citizenship will be abolished .
This provision was applicable in matters arising before the commencement of the Constitution but in matters arising after the commencement of the Constitution the citizenship Act . 1955 shall be dealt with in accordance with the provisions of the Citizenship Act .
The Supreme Court has held that it is the duty of the Government of India to determine whether or not a person has been deprived of the citizenship of any other country and then a state is treated as foreigners .
( पीर v. State of Kerala AIR 1966 SC 1966 ) ; Uttar Pradesh ( 1971 ) State of Uttar Pradesh v. पुलिस ( 1971 ) AIR 1965 SC 329 ) ;
Article 10 provides for every person to be a citizen of India subject to any of the provisions made in articles 5 to 10 or understood subject to the provisions of such a law .
In other words it means that a citizen ' s right to citizenship cannot be छीना apart from parliamentary legislation .
( Ibrahim Wazir ( राज्य ) Bombay State ( AIR 1954 SC 229 ) .
The terms used in articles 5 and 10 have been interpreted in such a way that all persons under them are in jail during trial or who are undergoing imprisonment .
राज्य State v. Prabhakar AIR 1966 SC 1966 Sunil . v Delhi Administration AIR 1978 SC 1978 .

The power of Parliament to regulate the right of citizenship by law and the Citizenship Act 1955 1955 provides unfettered powers for enacting legislation on the acquisition and termination of citizenship of India and all matters connected therewith.
Accordingly the नागरिकता Parliament passed the Citizenship Act 1955 1955 providing for acquisition and termination of citizenship .
Thus all matters relating to the citizenship rights after the commencement of the Constitution are to be dealt with in accordance with its provisions .
The Act was amended in 1986 to tackle the situation created by the large - scale unlawful immigration into India from Bangladesh बांग्लादेश Sri Lanka and some African countries .
This amendment has resulted in greater acquisition of Indian citizenship .
The equality of opportunity in public employment under article 16 ( 1 ) and ( 2 ) for all citizens of India cannot be granted a distinction of equality of status in respect of any employment or employment under the State .
However the subsequent clauses ( 3 ) ( 4 ) ( 4 ) ( 4 ) and ( 5 ) provide four exceptional situations where ordinary rules of equality of opportunity can be broken .
On the basis of this right Parliament passed the Public Employment ( निवास ) Act 1957 .
The Act however provided for an exception in the case of Himachal Pradesh . Manipur Tripura and the Telangana region of Andhra Pradesh where residential qualifications were provided for a limited period not exceeding five years on the basis of backwardness of those areas .
In the case of संसद Rao v. Andhra Pradesh ( AIR 1970 SC 422 ) the Supreme Court gave an opinion that a part of the Act could provide for the whole of the state and not for a part of it .
Clause 4 as a second exception in article 16 provides special powers for reservation of appointments and posts in favour of any deprived sections of citizens .
And this condition can refer not only to the numerical inadequacy of representation in services but also to the qualitative one .
In other words these powers can be exercised not only for reservation of appointments but also for providing reservation in selective posts and posts filled by promotion .
The people do the first and most basic application of their sovereignty when they provide a Constitution in which the various organs of the State are represented and exercised by certain forces .
The Constitution in the federal polity inter alia lays down the powers between the various organs of the states at the level of a federal or federal level and at the other level of units .
The Constitution of a country can also be said to be such देश as may lay down the basic principles of its polity and on the basis of which all other laws and executive functions of the State are subject to their validity and validity .
The Constitution is a living organism of active institutions .
It continues to flourish. and grows .
Much depends on how the courts of the country interpret it and enforce it what conventions and conventions are born around it .
Constitutional law is generally symbolic of the fundamental law of the country in the provisions of the Constitution .
This is particularly concerned with the basic features of the distribution of powers between the various parts of the state and between the Union and the units .

The Government of India Act 1935 1935 intended to provide for a federal structure .

In the beginning the समवेत used to meet themselves in the ancient Greek City States or in the urban states and in the Vedic times .
Thus people used their powers directly to decide the affairs of the state and such a polity could be termed direct democracy .

That is why all direct democracy soon ended up all over the world except in some of Switzerland where people still hold decisions directly on various matters .
Modern democracy has become necessary to have a representative democracy where people exercise their sovereignty through their elected representatives .

The most remarkable feature of the Government of India Act शासन 1935 was that it envisaged a All - India Federation of Indian States formed to join the British provinces and the Union .
Till the Round Table Conference in 1930 India was a completely unitary state and whatever powers the provinces possessed were given to them by the Centre .
The 1935 Act provided for the first time a federal system consisting of not only the provinces of the Governors of India but also the Chief Ministers and the princely states .
It eventually dissolved the concept of a unitary system under which the British had so far been administered .
The principle of the Constitution of 1919 was decentralisation rather than a Federation .
In normal circumstances थे had become free from central control in that area .
Under this Act Burma was divorced from India and two new provinces of Orissa and Sind were formed .
In view of the proposed scheme at the Centre the eleven provinces of the गवर्नरों Governors were completely से except for certain specific purposes ”.
In other words the , provinces were given a separate legal personality .
Moreover the Parliament has the power to produce or create a Legislative Council in a State by a simple procedure which is not required to amend the Constitution .
If the Legislative Assembly of a State passes a resolution to this effect by a special majority it could be done by the Parliament Act .
The last but important is that Parliament exercises some control over the states by the Governor .
As we know the President is a part of Parliament and at the same time it is the head of the executive of the Union .
The Governor of the states is appointed by him and he holds office during the pleasure of the President .
Moreover the Governor - General may make provisions for the exercise of the functions of the Governor of the State in such contingency as it thinks fit .
All these facts however do not mean that there are merely administrative agents of the Union in India .
No one in his own field is subject to one another .
In the words of the Constitution the states are as sovereign in their sphere as the Centre is vested in the Constitution .
The scheme of provincial autonomy envisaged by the Act provided for a executive and a legislature in every province .
The Council of Ministers was made responsible for the Legislature and could dismiss it by passing a no - confidence motion .
The Legislature could exercise some control over the administration through questions and supplementary questions .
But the legislature could not accept or reject nearly 80 per cent of the grant - in - aid .
In the legislative sphere the legislature could pass laws on subjects included in the Concurrent List though in case of conflict the federal law would have been effective .

The Secretary - General is the third important officer of the House.
He is the Chairman ' s Deputy Speaker in all parliamentary functions and activities and in all matters relating to procedure and practice .
As a permanent official who is the head of the House Table and continues to work as a link between the changing various Houses and अध्यक्षों General Secretary is the custodian of parliamentary conventions and traditions and has the wisdom of himself .
The Secretary - General discharges several legislative functions administrative and executive functions and provides services and facilities to the members .
He is the highest incharge of the Watch and Ward Organisation and the security in the precincts of the Parliament property .
The Parliament Library also works under the aegis of its Library Research संसद Reference Documentation and Information Services .
He is responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the buildings and buildings of Parliament and other properties .
As the supreme official of the parliamentary Museum and Archives he is the custodian of the heritage of Parliament and the keeper of all parliamentary records .
He is the head of the legislative services and the Secretariat of the House and is responsible for its administration to maintain discipline and to ensure that the secretarial work of the House and its Committees is conducted properly and efficiently .
It provides secretarial assistance and staff to all the Parliamentary Committees and is available to them for advice.
Its role is that of a friend philosopher thinker and guide for members and committees .
Members of various political parties approach him for advice .
To a large extent it has to play the same role as impartiality .
He should be fully conscious and should be a man of quick action .
The person who occupies the office of the Secretary - General is required to be a brilliant person and to be competent in the manifold functions of the Parliament is so much more technical and more complex in all grades .
Work is organised in such a way that each unit acts on a particular subject or aspect of parliamentary life and carries with it brilliant staff who are technically competent and who discharge their duties efficiently.
It is the duty of the Secretary - General to see that adequate staff should be trained to fill up the gaps which have remained vacant from time to time and a high level of parliamentary work .
It is therefore vitally dependent on the personality and approach of the person holding the office of the Secretary - General .
His approach and perspective are always totally non - partisan and objective .
He is elected from among the officers who have done commendable job in serving the Parliament in performing various posts in the Secretariat of the House .
The Speaker has the authority to choose and appoint him .
Once appointed he will continue to occupy his office until he attains the prescribed age of निवृत्ति which is 60 years old .
It cannot be criticised in the House and it cannot be discussed in its affairs outside the House or outside .

The Lok Sabha Secretariat is altogether separate and under the control of the Speaker to give independent advice and its directions can be implemented without any outside interference or internal pressure .
The Secretary - General applies to the members and the members of the House to whom they receive the records and the documents sent by the members on behalf of the President .

( ii ) The second reading of the Bill is the most elaborate and significant one being examined at this stage .
The second reading or thinking has two stages which can be called the first stage and the second .
In the first stage there is a general discussion on the whole Bill - LRB - i. e. the whole - RRB - on the principle and not on its details .
At this stage the House may at any rate specify a Select Committee of the House or a Joint Committee of the two Houses or operate upon it to elicit opinion or to think directly .
To specify a committee a Bill may be referred to a Select Committee or a Joint Committee .
The members of the Select Committee are drawn from among the members of the House to which the Bill has been introduced .
In the case of a Joint Committee members of both the Houses are represented ; in such a case the ratio between members of the Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha shall be 2 .
The Chairman of the joint committee is appointed by the Presiding Officer of the House in which a Bill has been introduced .
The Bill then passes through the Committee stage and the Bill is presented in the House as a विधेयक report .
After the report of a Select or Joint Committee on the Bill is presented to the House the Minister may make a motion on the three - LRB - i - RRB - to be referred to the Bill in the form of reference to the Bill (
Then the debates are confined to a Bill as reported by the Committee and cannot be discussed again on the principles of the Bill because when a motion for reference to the Bill is passed the House is pledged to the Bill .
The second stage is followed by a clause - hit consideration on the Bill or on the Bill as reported by the Select / Joint Committee .
Each clause is placed separately before the House for discussion .
Revision may be made subject to the conditions of admissibility immediately after the clause is placed before the House .
Block - wise views are often long and difficult as each clause is ordinarily discussed separately and discussed on each amendment ( except for such amendments as the सदन for which the mover back is back - to the House .
Amendments which are accepted become part of the Bill .
In other cases the stages of a Bill are the same as in the case of government Bills .

The Parliament of India exchanges delegations goodwill missions etc with foreign Parliaments and regularly participates under the Conferences organised by the Indian Parliamentary Group under the auspices of the Inter - Parliamentary Union and the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association .
The Parliamentary Union is a Union of Parliamentary Groups formed in National Parliaments to promote personal contacts among members of all Parliaments and to unite them for joint action to take part in the task of setting up parliamentary institutions and helping their development .
The union meets twice a year and member countries are host .
The Commonwealth Parliamentary Association is the association of Commonwealth Parliamentarians with the object to promote understanding and cooperation among themselves and to promote the study and respect of parliamentary institutions .
The Association meets in Conference annually and assists in holding Seminars on Parliamentary Practice and Procedure at regional levels .

The problems of minorities accentuated the need for a formal declaration of fundamental rights in the text of the Constitution itself by certain वाद or courts .
Broadly speaking the fundamental rights incorporated in the Part III of the Constitution are those which cannot be ruled by the individual against the state .
For example an executive action can be challenged in the Supreme Court or in the High Courts .
If these laws or executive action do not come under any of the restrictions mentioned in the Constitution they can be held unconstitutional and invalid .
Thus the Constitution also lays down the mechanism and mechanism of enforcement of fundamental rights .

Conclusion The Constitution of India is one of the most comprehensive documents .
It is unique in many respects .
It cannot be fitted into a certain mould - structure or model .
It is a combination of rigid and flexible federal and unitary संसदीय and presidential and parliamentary forms .
It attempts to balance between the fundamental rights of individuals on the one hand and the social economic interests of the people on the other .
Moreover it presents a middle path between the principles of parliamentary sovereignty and judicial superiority .

The final authority in all matters relating to the House and within the House is vested in him .
Independence and impartiality are the two important attributes of office .
His place is larger than all the ministers of the prime minister except that of the prime minister .
His salary and allowances are charged on the Consolidated Fund of India - that is they do not require parliamentary approval .
His conduct cannot be discussed except on substantive motion .
He does not vote in the House except when there is a vote on both sides on a motion .
It is always done according to established parliamentary principles and conventions when it is a common vote .
When elected he withdraws himself from all the activities of his party .
He does not hold the post of a party ; he does not participate in any party meetings or activities ; he is away from political controversies and campaigns .
It performs these functions in accordance with the provisions of the Constitution and the Rules of Procedure and Conduct of Business in Lok Sabha .
In all parliamentary matters his decision is final .
The residuary powers of reference to cases which are not specifically provided in the Rules are vested with the Speaker .
While doing so he may ask a member or the government to provide facts and information which he thinks necessary to arrive at a decision .
The Speaker has powers to govern the functioning of the House in a peaceful and orderly manner .
He can order a member to discontinue his speech or to withdraw words or expressions which may be अभद्र or vulgar .
He can also order that without his permission anything said by a member shall not be incorporated in the proceedings and that anything found असंसदीय may be excluded from the proceedings .

As a result of chaos in the House the Speaker may ask a member to withdraw from the House for a day or for any part of the day or offer a suitable motion for spreading extreme disorder .
It is the Speaker ' s duty to keep all members under discipline and to take appropriate care with them and to agree to their responsibilities and obligations .
Whenever he speaks in the middle or rises in order to propose questions or to put questions to vote . or give some comments or rulings he must be heard from peace .
It is also held by the Speaker whether a prima facie case becomes a matter relating to a breach of privilege or contempt of the House or a matter of conduct of a member should be referred to a Committee for investigation .
No further action is taken if he does not give his consent .
The Speaker also protects the honour of individuals from the statements made by आरोपात्मक सदन or करने in the House and may prevent a member from making such statements if they are based on the evidence or the nature of the statement .
The Speaker has to be responsive to the atmosphere in the House .
He reports the decision of the House to the authorities concerned and tells them that such decisions should be followed .
All Parliamentary Committees in the Lok Sabha are constituted by it or by the House .
They act under her control and are self - controlled .
The Business Advisory Committee . functions under the Chairmanship of the General Purposes Committee and the Rules Committee directly .
It determines the financial matters which fall within the exclusive jurisdiction of the Lok Sabha .
If he certifies that a Bill is a wealthy Bill his decision is final .

A no - confidence motion holds confidence in the Lok Sabha until it holds office .
To find out this belief there is a provision for a motion in the , Rules which is called a no - confidence motion .
There is no express provision in the Constitution regarding the individual responsibility of a minister in his department for doing or not doing anything .
It is a collective responsibility .
Therefore a resolution expressing the lack of faith in the whole council of ministers is admitted and no resolution expressing individual belief in a minister is in law .

( A ) The Budget is presented in our Parliament in two parts : i . e . a railway budget and a general budget .
The basic idea behind presenting a separate budget for the railways is to secure stability in civil estimates by providing assured contribution by the railways .
The Railway Budget is presented to the Lok Sabha by the Minister of Railways in the third week of February every year and the General Budget Finance is presented to the last working day of the month at 5 o 'clock .
While presenting the budget a Budget speech is actually one of the most important speeches in Parliament .
This speech occurs in two parts : " A " general economic survey of the country and Part B contains " taxation proposals for the ensuing financial year .
At the end of the speech of the Finance Minister in the Lok Sabha a copy of the Budget is placed on the Table of the Rajya Sabha .
Immediately thereafter the Minister introduces a Bill containing the taxation proposals of the government .
( A ) Discussion on the Budget is an important advisory body .
In the process of passing the Budget there is a serious and complete discussion between the two Houses of Parliament .
A few days after the budget is presented .
This allows members to fully study the text of the budget and meet the time required for considering financial proposals .
Budget is discussed in two stages i General discussions and then in detail on demands for grants and voting .
Also the opportunity of पर on various financial proposals arises during consideration and passing of Appropriation Bill and Finance Bill .
( A ) General discussion begins with a general debate on the Budget which takes place in both the Houses of Parliament for three or four days .
First at this stage members consider the general aspects of fiscal and economic policies of the government and do not go into details of taxation and expenditure .
Thus a general debate allows every House to express its views .
Then the Government becomes aware of the procedure in the later stages of a particular proposal .
It is to be noted that in accordance with the power conferred by the Rajya Sabha it does not matter with the budget except with the general discussion .
( 2 ) Discussion on demands for grants - in - aid in the second stage discussions and voting on demands for grants .
Generally speaking separate demands are made for the grants offered by each ministry .
This demands relate to a part of the budget expenditure and are in the nature of request made by the Executive to the Lok Sabha to pay the amount demanded .
Demands are to be moved in the form of a motion but in practice they are accepted ; they are offered by the Chair to save the time of the House .
The demands are discussed and the policy and functioning of the ministry is examined in depth .
Time is allotted to each ministry for discussing demands .
The members can disapprove of the policy of the ministry or suggest measures for economy in the administration or to focus on specific local grievances .
The members can do so by presenting a subsidiary motion to the basic motion for demands for grants .
These subsidiary motions are called ' Cut ' in parliamentary language .
The Business Advisory Committee fixes a limit from time to time to sanction all demands for grants including a particular demand and a budget .
As the time limit for demand arises the process of winding up the discussion is applied and the demand is placed to vote .
Similarly on the last day allotted to all the demands for which the demands have not been disposed of by the time being disposed of are kept for voting whether or not they have been discussed .
This process is called the गिलोटिन .
With this a discussion on demands for grants ended .
The experience that scrutiny by permanent committees relating to departments revealed that every year prior to the enforcement of the गिलोटिन only a handful of ministries or three ministries could never be discussed in the House on the Demands for Grants and other Government .
The seventeen Standing Committees of the Parliament established with other functions have been entrusted with the responsibility of considering the Demands for Grants of the respective Ministries and Departments and reporting to the House before voting on demand .
After the 1994 - 95 demands were presented to Parliament both the Houses were adjourned for a month to examine them and discuss them .
During the 1994 budget session these committees presented 48 reports on the demand for grants of 1994 - 95 .
( c ) Appropriation Bills.
This Bill means that the Government has a statutory right to exercise expenditure from the Consolidated Fund as is evident from its name .
The method of considering and passing an Appropriation Bill is the same in the case of any other Bill except that a dispute is confined to cases where no amendments have been made nor discussed during the debate .
After the Bill is passed by the Lok Sabha the Speaker certifies it as a Money Bill and is sent to the Rajya Sabha .
The Rajya Sabha has no power to amend or reject a Bill and has to give its consent to the Bill .
Thereafter the Bill is presented to the President for his assent .
( d ) Finance Bills : All the financial proposals of the government for the coming year are included in a Bill called Finance Bill ; this Bill is ordinarily introduced in the Lok Sabha after the budget is presented every year .
The Bills are discussed on matters concerning general administration and local grievances to the Union Government .
While the Government ' s policy is generally enough to criticise details of certain estimates cannot be discussed .
In short the whole administration is revised but questions already discussed cannot be discussed .
After the Bill has been introduced it must be discussed and passed by Parliament within 75 days and assented to by the President .
Vote on Account In a democratic set - up the government endeavours to give full opportunity to Parliament to discuss the provisions of the budget and the taxes proposals .
The procedure for passing the Budget is followed by the presentation of the Budget and bringing into consideration the demands for grants and adopting Appropriation and Finance Bills and generally goes beyond the commencement of the current financial year .
So long as the Parliament does not approve of the demands it is necessary that the Government has enough money to carry out the administration of the country .
Therefore a special provision has been made for vote on account whereby the Lok Sabha has been empowered to grant an advance for one part of the financial year until completion of the budget process .
During an election year if such anticipate that the House takes more than two months from the main demand and the Appropriation Bill a vote on account may be taken for a longer period i. e. three or four months .
According to custom vote on account is considered a formality and Lok Sabha passes without discussion .
Vote on account is passed on a general discussion on the budget and discussion on demands for grants is still started .
In case of railway budget which is passed before 31 March no vote on vote is accepted but if necessary a vote may be taken in the election year .
The demands for supplementary and additional grants cannot be spent without the sanction of excess amounts paid by Parliament .
If the amount sanctioned for any specific service is found insufficient for the purposes of that year or a new service which is not envisaged in the budget of that year the President may draw the necessary amount of supplementary or extra expenditure .
if any
All such cases of expenditure are brought into the notice of the Parliament by the Comptroller and Auditor General through his report on the Appropriation Accounts .
The cases of extra expenditure are then examined by the Public Accounts Committee which makes recommendations on regularisation in its report to the House .
Supplementary Demands for Grants are moved to the House before the end of the financial year and the demands for additional grants are actually met after the expenditure actually incurred and the financial year is referred to .
Formulation of a legislative procedure ( a ) Constitution of Bills relating to ordinary Bills as soon as a legislative proposal is proposed the ministry concerned finds what its political powers administrative finances and other consequences could be .
If other ministries or the state governments are also concerned they are consulted .
Professionals and various interest groups such as business labour agriculture and industry associations if considered necessary are also consulted .
Thereafter the Bill is examined in detail by the administrative ministry in consultation with all concerned authorities and given final shape .
After this whole process the Bill is ready to be brought before the House .
It can be moved by the minister concerned either in the Houses of Parliament .
To permit a Bill to be produced a minister has to furnish seven days with such notice two copies duly corrected by a Bill are sent to the Secretary - General of the House where a Bill is to be moved .
After the Bill is found to be complete in all respects by the Secretariat it is included in the List of Business on a date fixed by the Speaker or Chairman as the case may be .
Normally copies of the Bill should be made available to members at least two days prior to that date .

It is obvious that the framers of the Constitution had made it natural for the existence of parliamentary committees and left to the Houses to provide for them in their Rules .
Under the rules of the Lok Sabha each such Committee is not the Parliamentary Committee suo के to be composed of members of Parliament .
In fact the संसद Consultative Committees do not report to anybody but merely provide a forum for informal exchange of views between MPs and ministers interested in their departments.

Types of Committees There are two types of Parliamentary Committees in India ( i . e . Standing Committees and ii ad hoc Committees .
Standing Committees are those Committees which are elected by the House every year or on time nominated by the Speaker or Chairman and duly constituted by the House on specific matters appointed by the Speaker or by the Speaker .
Standing Committees : Standing Committees.
The objective of their recommendations is to keep the administration wary of relying on these policies and programmes operational by economy to function faster and faster .
Reports of these Committees have earned them considerable respect from all sections of the society both official and non - official .
Every recommendation is carefully analysed and the administration always endeavours to remove the faults and shortcomings brought by the Committees and to act as per the recommendations made by the Committees .
The financial committees have developed adequate procedures to ensure that the government makes due consideration to their recommendations and that the committees should not be entertained .
The progress made in the implementation of the recommendations and the differences in committees and in the Government are brought to the notice of the House by way of Action Taken report made .
The elaborate and effective procedure for follow - up of the recommendations made by these Committees is essentially an Indian innovation to parliamentary procedures prevalent elsewhere .
The three Financial Committees are elected by the House for one another .
Ministers can neither become members of these Committees nor can they be asked to appear before them for evidence .
Their Chairmen are nominated by the Speaker .
संसदीय Enquiry Committees . In Parliamentary democracy लोगों as we have here have the inherent right of the people to submit petitions to Parliament with a view to providing grievances and seeking redressal thereof and constructive suggestions on matters of public importance .
This right is exercised through the Committee on Petitions .
Each House has a petition committee .
The Committee has 15 members in the Lok Sabha and 10 members in the Rajya Sabha .
The function of the Committee on Petitions is to examine every petition referred to the Committee after presentation to the House .
The Committee reports to the House on specific complaints made in the petitions after taking such evidence as he thinks fit .
The Committee suggests remedial measures either in a particular case under review or in a general way to prevent such cases in the future .
The Committee also considers representations including letters and telegrams received from various individuals and associations which are not covered by the rules relating to petitions and gives directions for their proper settlement .
The Committee has already made significant work in providing parliamentary support to the masses in the matter of redressal of their legitimate grievances .
It has proved to be a real aid to the victims of sub - उप and . who have no remedy or relief elsewhere .
The Committee has 15 members in the Lok Sabha and has 10 members in the Rajya Sabha .
To ensure that the administration has exercised effective and continuous control over the possibility of misuse of such power ; each House of the House has its own Committee on Subordinate Legislation .
Each House consists of 15 members nominated by the Speaker / Chairman .
Normally the , committee is reconstituted every year .
The Committee examines them whether suitable provisions have been made to place their rules or orders on the Table of the House .
If the Committee concludes that the provisions made in the Bill delegated to delegated powers should be revoked or amended or if any amendments thereto they may report to the House before the consideration of the Bill is initiated .
The Committee consists of 30 members - LRB - 20 Lok Sabha - RRB - and 10 from the Rajya Sabha and these members are elected by different Houses of Parliament from amongst their members .
The main functions of the Committee are to consider the reports of the Commissioner of the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes and report to Parliament the measures taken or required by the government .
The Committee also ensures that constitutional safeguards are implemented effectively for these backward communities .
( six ) Committees which provide services are a few of the Committees of Parliament to examine the various kinds of facilities and services and other matters relating to the functioning of members of both the Houses of Parliament .
They are: General Purposes Committee , House Committee संसद Library Committee and Members of Parliament.
General Purposes Committee : Each House has a General Purposes Committee .
The Presiding Officer of the concerned House is the ex officio Chairman of the Committee .
The Committee also has a position like the Deputy Speaker or Deputy Chairman . a member of the Table . Chairmen of all the Standing Committees in that House are recognised leaders of parties and other members nominated by the Presiding Officer .

When behaviour begins in the House . when the House is in session the first rule of behaviour of members on the floor of the House takes place a few minutes before the commencement of the meeting .

The right to equality before law and equal protection of laws Article 14 of the Constitution enunciates the fundamental right of every person not to be denied to him as equal protection against laws in the territory of India .
The protection provided by this article is not limited to citizens but covers all persons .
It embodies the principle contained in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights that all are equal before law and deserve equal protection without any discrimination .
In singular in the term of equality before law means the same thing as those of law or of law or of justice .
On the other hand the term ' का ' like ' conservation ' in the " term " explains clearly the statutory law and the provision made by it orders the state to ensure that all laws are made without any distinction .
But so far the Supreme Court has not seen any such distinction .
In fact न्यायमूर्ति Chief Justice शास्त्री Shastri has expressed the view that the second term was the primary result of the first term and it is very difficult to imagine the situation in which laws will not be the law of equality .
( State of West Bengal v. Anwar AH Government AIR 1952 SC 75 ) .
Laws should be applied to all in one case .
The Supreme Court has held that there is often a need for separate treatment in relation to different needs of different classes of people .
According to भारत Lal v. Union of India AIR 1951 SC 41 .
If the classification is not reasonable and does not meet the two terms mentioned above the impugned legislation or executive action would be clearly arbitrary and would constitute a denial of equality under article 14 .
Therefore wherever the state ' s action takes place whether it is a legislative or executive or an authority under article 12 - LRB - article 14 - RRB - becomes active and the action of the state is cancelled .
Thus the new approach enunciated by the Supreme Court has expanded the scope of enforcement of article 14 and there was no need for any discrimination against others .

The Constitution of India has established a federal polity since the legislative powers between the Union and the States are distributed between the executive and the financial powers.
But it is very doubtful whether the Indian polity is federal or federal .
The word का was nowhere used in the text of the Constitution.
In fact the proposal to name India as a फेडरशन was specifically rejected in the Constituent Assembly .
In Article 1 of the Constitution India has been described as the Union of India .

The judiciary is also integrated and not divided into the Union and the States .
But in short it may be said that there is a difference in opinion about whether Indian polity is federal unitary or quasi - federal or quasi - federal or it is a polity which is unitary in spirit .
At present there are 25 states in the Union of India and seven Union Territories - as mentioned in the First Schedule to the Constitution .
The executive has the right to prepare a budget .
The Constitution provides for an annual statement of estimated receipts and expenditure to be placed before Parliament .
It has full freedom to suggest how to collect finances in order to meet its expenses so that the Government can take all possible initiatives in financial matters .
No taxes cannot be legally levied and no dues can be obtained from the treasury without special parliamentary powers .
The 19th century British idea of parliamentary control over the executive is no longer valid even in the ब्रिटिश of ब्रिटिश .
The Government of Parliament is under constant control .
The ministers sometimes find out by asking questions about what departments are under them and what are the defects which require further attention .
In addition to these other procedural measures are those of Calling Attention Notices .
A member may with the previous permission of the Speaker take notice of a Minister on a matter of urgent public importance and request him to make a statement on the matter .
Members can also write to the concerned Minister ask for information which they need and are given general information .
Another medium for achieving institutional information is the reports of various parliamentary committees .

Immediately after the Universal Declaration of Human Rights the Constitution of India consisted in keeping with the contemporary democratic and humanitarian temper and constitutional practice in other countries of the world .
It was a proof of how keen the Constitution - maker was to incorporate and implement the basic principles enunciated in the Universal Declaration .
Moreover in view of the special problems of minorities and the need to assure them of their fullest protection the basic rights enshrined in our Constitution were necessitated .
In the Preamble values of liberty and equality befitting the dignity of man have been announced with great emphasis .
These fundamental rights substantially cover all the traditional civil and political rights enumerated in articles 2 to 21 of the Universal Declaration .
Equality before law and Equal protection of all laws ( article 14 ) protection of conviction in respect of offences ( article 20 ) protection of life and personal liberty ( article 32 ) protection of fundamental rights under certain conditions .
But there are certain rights which can be claimed only by the citizens such as religion religion race sex or place of birth ( article 15 ) equality of opportunity and respect of public employment ( article 16 ) .
Originally article 19 ( l ) and article 31 contained the right to property to acquire hold and sell property subject to the right of compulsory acquisition for public purpose by the authority of law .
But when the Constitution ( 44th Amendment ) Act 1978 omitted sub - clause ( f ) of article 19 ) and all Article 31 (

Article 33 - 35 empowers the Parliament to give special attention to the armed forces .
It is true that the fundamental human rights enshrined in the Constitution of India are hedged in by numerous limitations and restraints .
The fundamental rights conferred upon the individual are in the form of restrictions or restrictions on the actions of the state .

While trying to avoid the possible conflict between the rights of the individual and the needs of the community on the one hand the necessary restrictions on fundamental rights were imposed on the other the more positive Directive Principles of State Policy .
It is therefore clear that these constitutional directives are not merely moral precepts but are positive mandates and are regarded as part of the human rights provisions of the Constitution .
But the Directive Principles did not give any legal rights which arose as a breach of them nor do they give any power to the legislature .
Speaking in the Constituent Assembly .
Ambedkar had categorically stated that the Directive Principles were not intended to be mere pious declarations .
The Directive Principles are an effective part of the Constitution and form an important part of this vision for the Constitution wants to achieve the ideal of a democratic state in the Preamble and to realise the ideal of that social and economic revolution .
The Preamble is a relation between the Fundamental Rights and the Directive Principles .
Both the Fundamental Rights and the Directive Principles are the soul of the Constitution .
It is now clear that there is no essential dichotomy between the rights and duties or between the Fundamental Rights and the Directive Principles .
They complement and supplement each other .
While presenting a proposal to the Select Committee on the Constitution ( First Amendment ) Bill 1951 1951 Jawaharlal Nehru refers to the possibility of a struggle between the Fundamental Rights and the Directive Principles and the manner in which the Constitution has arrived .
But where a party is not in a position to form a government on its own it is possible to have a number of पार्टी and there are also variations in the number of groups .
In the case of the sovereignty of Parliament the Supreme Court has also expressed various perspectives ( See Union of India ) - LRB - . v. State of Madras ( मद्रास v. राज्य AIR 1951 SC भारत ) .
But in the Gopalan case it is held that within the specified limits of its powers the Parliament is supreme .
The function of Parliament is to make the main functioning of the legislature by law .
Under article 245 - 246 Parliament can make laws for the whole or any part of India within its jurisdiction under the division of legislative powers between the Union and the States .
Legislation in relation to the Union List can only be made by Parliament .
Both the Union and the States have concurrent power to legislate in the concurrent framework .
If there is any conflict between the Union and the State laws the former prevails ( article 254 ) .
The residuary powers also vest in the Parliament ( article शक्तियां ) and entry of the Union List ( 97 ) .
In many articles the Parliament has been empowered to make laws on such powers in various matters such as संसद ' Parliament may by law except otherwise provided by law and not by Parliament by law . "

Parliamentary control over public finance : levy or revision of taxes and voting of supplies and grants is the most important checks on the Executive so that it cannot exercise arbitrary powers .
No taxes can be legally levied and no expenditure incurred from the Government exchequer without specific parliamentary authorization ( articles 114 - 116 and 265 ) .
There are several channels to ensure administrative प्रशासनिक parliamentary devices like संसदीय questions discussions on various motions like संसदीय scrutiny by the संसद Committee and the Minister who actually represents the Parliament and controls his department on behalf of Parliament .

Judges of the Supreme Court shall be paid such salaries as may be specified by Parliament by law and unless such decision - making shall be paid in the second list ( article 125 ) .
When the office of the Chief Justice of India is vacant or when the Chief Justice is unable to perform the duties of his office the President shall appoint one of the other judges of the court and he shall perform the duties of the Chief Justice .
If at any time there is no quorum of the judges of that court to conduct or continue the session of the Supreme Court at any time the Chief Justice of India is entitled to appoint such judges as the High Court considered fit .
He can do so only with the previous consent of the President and consultation with the Chief Justice of the concerned High Court .
The judge so appointed would have a duty to give priority to the duties of the Supreme Court .
The Chief Justice of India may appoint a retired judge of the Supreme Court or a retired judge of the Supreme Court of India for a period as much as he thinks fit as a judge of the Supreme Court .
It may also be with the consent of the President and the person to be so appointed ( articles 127 and 128 ) .
The power and jurisdiction of the Supreme Court :
On a question of law or fact of public importance the President may ask for the opinion of the Supreme Court on which he thinks it expedient to obtain such an opinion .
After such reference from the President the Supreme Court will report on it to the President after a hearing which he thinks fit .
The President is free to recognise him or not .
The President may by such reference make a treaty agreement थी covenant engagement . . or any other instrument which had been entered into or executed before the commencement of this Constitution and thereafter the Supreme Court may have .
Under article 138 the Supreme Court shall have such additional jurisdiction and powers with respect to any of the matters in the Union List .
This enlarges the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court and provides it with very special jurisdiction to hear cases of urgent nature directly and in its original jurisdiction .
The due process gives ample scope to the Supreme Court to protect the rights of its citizens .
It can declare laws violative of these rights void not only on substantive grounds of being unlawful but also on procedural grounds of being unreasonable.
It is not expected to consider its reasonableness suitability or policy complications .
The Supreme Court pronounces its judgement on a specified case by a specified petition .
It does not give advice or advice on general direction .
There should be an aggrieved person who petitions the validity of the statute which has adversely affected his rights .
It has to show that the law has brought about any direct injury or danger of immediate access and the damage that has been complained to is वाद .
This judgement allows individuals and citizens to seek judicial relief in the interest of the public .
The effect of law declared against the Constitution would be binding on all courts within the territory of India under Article 141 .
Therefore if the Supreme Court declares any law to be a legislative competence or a violation of fundamental rights it will be binding on all courts in the territory of India .
Independence of the judiciary : In a representative democracy administration of justice assumes special significance since the rights of individuals are questioned and need to be protected by the intervention of the executive or legislative .
The independent and supreme judiciary in a federal polity is an essential requisite particularly between the Union Government and governments of the constituent units and a functional division of powers between the executive legislature and judiciary .
An independent and impartial judiciary is an essential requisite for ensuring human rights and protecting democracy .
Only an independent judiciary can act effectively as the guardian of the rights of the individual and the Constitution .
The Constitution provides for a High Court for each state .
However Parliament may by law establish a common High Court for two or more States or for two or more States and a Union territory ( articles 114 and न्यायालय ) .
A higher court issues a lower court or tribunal and aims to prohibit it from exceeding its jurisdiction .
Apart from the above - mentioned High Courts under Article 226 can issue other directions and orders in the interest of justice ( . v. न्यायालय AIR 1954 SC 440 ) .

The Government of India Act 1935 1935 proposed that there should be a federal polity in India - a central government and the Provinces deriving its jurisdiction and powers by direct devolution from the Crown .
Since a limited government was established at the provincial level the nationalists naturally asked for more powers for provincial legislatures .
When the Constituent Assembly met in 1946 and early 1947 the idea was that there should be a Federation ( including a Centre with limited powers .

When Partition became a reality there was no need to appease the Muslim League and restrict the powers of the Union Government .
If there is any contradiction between the laws made by Parliament under article 249 and 250 and the laws made by the Legislatures of States the laws made by Parliament would be over and the law of the state would be अप्रवर्तनीय and 251 Law made by Parliament .
According to article 252 two or more State Legislatures by passing a resolution may ask Parliament to make laws on any matter in the State List .

Administrative linkages provide for regulation of administrative relations between Articles 256 to 265 .
It is common in federal systems that the administrative relations between the Union and the States are suffering from ग्रस्त .
The Constitution of India seeks to achieve a harmonious relationship between the two stages .
It provides that the executive powers of the State Government are to be exercised in such a way as to ensure compliance with the laws made by Parliament .
The executive of the Union also has the power to give directions to the States which seem to be necessary for the purpose .
Under article 258 the President may with the consent of a state government entrust to that Government or its officers functions in relation to any matter to which the executive power of the Union is extended .
Similarly under Article 258 the Governor of a State may with the consent of the Government of India entrust to that Government or its officers functions in relation to any matter to which the executive power of the State is extended .

The संवैधानिक Report . 1918 - 22 is known as the Report on constitutional reforms - LRB - संवैधानिक - RRB - or the भारतीय report .

There is no term on the power to amend i . e . a Constitution which cannot be amended .
The fundamental rights guaranteed under the Constitution ( Part III ) are subject to parliamentary power of constitutional amendment .
In Golak Nath ' s case the Supreme Court reversed its earlier decisions by a majority of 6 - 5 and said that the Constitution did not carry out any amendments or powers of legislation .
In 1973 the Supreme Court in the गोलकनाथ Bharati v. State of Kerala ( AIR 1973 SC गोलकनाथ ) reviewed the decision of the Golak Nath case .
10 of the 13 judges held that article 368 itself contained the power of constitutional amendment and the law of Article 13 ( 2 ) did not assimilate the amendment of the Constitution .
Accordingly the law declared in Golak Nath case was overthrown .
Regarding the question whether the power of amendment under article 368 is arbitrary and infinite : Seven Judges with a majority judgement : the power to amend under article 368 is such a limitation .
But what is the infrastructure ? it has not been explained by the majority and the question remained controversial .
In the मामले case after this decision the Constitution ( 42वां Amendment ) Act 1976 added clause 4 and 5 in Art. 368 and the शक्तियों of the powers to amend Parliament were reduced .
This was the first occasion when people were heard listening to the people ' s voice in making legislation and influencing the Government .
It also played a great role in shaping the political future of the country .
When the country was struggling to overthrow foreign domination the assembled masses were struggling in the House .
The world saw how the foreign government was exposed to the wishes of the people or loses its defeat .
Undoubtedly the defeat did not make any difference to the government because the government formed by the nominated executive was not bound to give up .

On 4 November 1948 the Draft Constitution was produced in the Constituent Assembly and recommended for parliamentary system the Chairman of the Drafting Committee said that " the Draft Constitution " preferred more stability.
Though some sounds were heard against the idea of a parliamentary system the Draft Committee resolution was a very large majority in the committee and finally on January 26 1950 the Constitution of a free India was established with all its institutional framework and other institutions .
The three terms . i. e. representative parliamentary and democracy are the basic elements of our political system .
At the commencement of the first session after every general election to the Lok Sabha and at the commencement of the first session of each year the President addresses both Houses of Parliament assembled together and gives reasons for inviting the House meeting .
Further he may address either House of Parliament or both Houses assembled together and require the attendance of members for the purpose .
He has the right to send भेजने or any other message to the House in respect of a Bill pending in Parliament in such a way that the House may be asked to consider the matter as expeditiously as possible .
Some Bills may be introduced only after the recommendation of the President or may be proceeded .
According to the Constitution there are certain other functions which are required by the President .
Whenever necessary he appointed the Speaker and the executive Chairman of the Lok Sabha .
To summon a joint sitting in case of disagreement between the two Houses on a Bill .
The President is responsible for the Budget का of the Government every year called the Annual Financial Statement in the Constitution : संसद and Comptroller and Auditor - General of India - Union Public Service Commission . Special Members for Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes .
If his opinion is that the Anglo - Indian community does not have enough representation in the Lok Sabha he may nominate not more than two members to the House .
Other ministers are appointed by the President from the advice of the prime minister .
It may be added that the President does not have the opportunity to use his personal wish to appoint a Prime Minister .
But if such a situation arises that no party gets a clear majority in the Lok Sabha the President may use a नेता in choosing a leader who in his opinion is likely to support a majority in the House .
Prime Minister is usually a member of Lok Sabha but ministers are drawn to both Houses of Parliament .
A person can also be appointed a minister who is not a member of either House of Parliament but he has to vacate the office after six months unless in the meanwhile he is elected to either of the two Houses .
At the same time every minister holds office during the pleasure of the President and can be dismissed by him .
But since the President does so only on the advice of the prime minister this power actually rests with the prime minister .
The executive and the legislature have close ties and do not have any resistance or division .
The two have not been visualised as two distinct centres competing for power but as partners or सर्हभागीदारों in the business of के .
Ministers can be said in a way that it is a great executive committee of Parliament entrusted with the responsibility of governance on behalf of the parent body .
In other words the executive is not a separate or external body .
However there is a clear distinction between the functions of the Executive and the functions of the Parliament .
The business of the Parliament is to make laws give advice and to criticise public grievances .
The function of the executive is to govern albeit on the part of Parliament .
In the words of the First Secretary of the Indian Parliament :
The Parliament should not take any part in Government ' s responsibilities at any point because once the Parliament has begun to do so the responsibility of the Parliament and the executive becomes vague and inadequate .
Article 13 provides that Parliament may not make such legislation as the State Legislature or any other authority inconsistent with any fundamental right as defined in Part III of the Constitution .
The power of the Supreme Court and the High Courts has been conferred respectively for the enforcement of these rights by Article 32 226 .
के is detrimental to the provisions of the Constitution or rejects any of the fundamental rights .
It is sometimes assumed and often said that the function of a Legislature is to make laws and to carry out the functions of the Executive so the courts are to interpret the Constitution and the laws .
These are very misleading and false .
The state of the Union is divided into states .
A law made by a state can be applied only in the territory of that state .
The Union Parliament can make laws for the whole or any part of India .
Parliament also has the power to legislate राज्यक्षेत्रातीय i . e . a legislation created by it would not only apply to the people and property in the Indian territory but also to the Indian citizens residing abroad .
States do not have the power to make such legislation .
The Constitution provides for the distribution of legislative power between the Union and the States in three ways .
List I or the Union List contains 97 subjects only in respect of which Parliament can legislate .
List II or the State List contains 66 entries over which the State Legislatures can only legislate .
There are 47 items in the List III or the Concurrent List about which both Parliament and the State Legislatures can make laws .
While in their respective spheres allotted by the Constitution Parliament and the State Legislatures enjoy absolute autonomy the scheme of distribution of powers emphasises the general predominance of Parliament in the legislative sphere .
A treaty agreement or convention with a country or an international conference एसोसिएशन Association or other body on a subject which is in the state list even the Parliament has the power to make laws .
Even if asked by Parliament it can make laws on any matter in the state list .

It was therefore considered that any procedure should be devised whereby members may have the opportunity to approach the government on urgent matters .
In the modern parliamentary procedure the idea of arranging Calling Attention Notices in the Rules of Procedure is simply the gift of India .
In this case :
Sometimes it gives opportunity to members to criticise the government directly or indirectly and to bring out inadequate action in an important case .
A member with the previous permission of the Speaker / Chairman may take notice of a Minister on a matter of urgent public importance and request him to make a statement on that case .
The minister may make a short statement or ask for time to make a statement later .
The members' chief source for giving Calling Attention Notices is the daily newspaper .
Sometimes they may be given on the basis of private information of a member or on the correspondence with him .
Notices of Calling Attention have to be given by members in writing by 10. 10 .
No member can give two or more information for a meeting .
Notices on the same subject may be given by more than one member but names of more than five members are recorded on the agenda .
The Speaker sees the notice and selects one of them for a statement by the minister concerned at the House meeting the following day .
In some cases the Speaker may select two notifications for a meeting .
But if the Speaker is of the opinion that the matter is urgent that the Minister should make a statement on the same day he may in his discretion allow the calling - , to go on the same day on which he has .
The idea behind admitting Calling Attention Notices a day or more in advance is that it makes sufficient time for the minister concerned to gather facts about the matter raised and make a statement over time .
No more than two notices can be taken at a meeting to give notice to Ministers .
There is no debate on such a statement but every member in whose name is listed is permitted to ask a question for its explanation .
The main purpose of the Calling Attention Resolution is to make an authoritative statement on a matter of urgent nature .
This process does not involve any censure against the government as there is no regular discussion or voting on the motion .
Some of the subjects on which the ministers have been asked to make statements are as follows : trouble in any part of India ; in any part of the railway dispute ; arrest of railway undertakings ; and others who have been adversely affected by the courts .
While raising the matter the member is not permitted to deviate from the approved text of his statement .
The minister concerned writes to the member directly on matters raised under Rule 377 informing him of the Government ' s views and what action has been taken .
It is important to note that matters so raised are not included in the task list .
Even before the fourth session of the sixth Lok Sabha the use of Rule 377 for raising matters in the House has been limited but thereafter more liberal approach has been adopted to raise different matters of public importance more particularly in their constituencies .
It is seen that members are taking more and more support of this rule and this process has become very popular .

Statutory Resolutions : These resolutions may be moved by a minister and also by a non - official member .
They are known to be under this name because they are always brought into pursuance of a provision of the Constitution or an Act of Parliament and are rightly expected to submit resolutions within the stipulated period .

Joint - sitting of the two Houses : on a Bill the disagreement between the two Houses on a Bill causes an extraordinary situation in the matter of a deadlock .
Under the Constitution the President has the power to summon the Bill if the Bill has not व्यपगत due to the dissolution of Lok Sabha both Houses may be invited for joint - sitting purposes and for the purpose of voting .
Such a joint - sitting is presided over by the Speaker and the Secretary - General is assisted by the Deputy Speaker Lok Sabha .
At the Joint meeting the Rules of Procedure of the Lok Sabha apply .
In the Joint meeting only such amendments can be proposed which are necessitated by the delay in passing the Bill .
The decisions at such sittings are taken by a majority of the total members of both the Houses present and voting.
So far only two bills . i . e . the Dowry Prohibition Bill दहेज 1961 and the Banking Service Commission ( Repeal ) have been passed in the Joint meeting .
( 5 ) When a Bill is passed by both the Houses in a separate or joint sitting it is presented to the President for his assent .
If the President withdraws his assent the Bill ends .
The Rajya Sabha cannot reject a Money Bill nor can it amend any Bill .
If any of the recommendations made by the Rajya Sabha are accepted by the Lok Sabha the money Bill is deemed to have been passed by both the Houses with the recommendations accepted by the Lok Sabha .
If no recommendation given by the Rajya Sabha is accepted by the Lok Sabha the Bill shall be deemed to have been passed by both the Houses in the form passed by the Lok Sabha before the amendments is recommended by the Rajya Sabha .
Further if any passed and a Money Bill sent to him for the recommendation of the Rajya Sabha would not be deemed to be transferred to the Lok Sabha within a period of 14 days .
There is no question of disagreement between the two Houses in respect of a Money Bill as in the case of a simple Bill because it has the same power as the Lok Sabha in relation to ordinary Bills .
That is why there is no provision for a joint - sitting in the case of a Money Bill .

Generally speaking a Bill is a Finance Bill which relates to revenue or expenditure .

The recommendation of the President is not required to move it .

In a parliamentary system the Legislature has to lay down the policies of the Government ; it is necessary to make laws and oversee administration .
But in the modern state the scope and complexity of legislation and administrative functions have made it impossible for the legislature to adequately investigate and monitor the functioning of the administration .
The Government has vast and sophisticated administration machinery and organisation to carry out its complex tasks which have expert and experienced civil servants but these are largely absent in the legislature .
Through parliamentary devices like questions and debates it can keep a watch over the administration .
Parliamentary monitoring is more effective and meaningful in this respect the Parliament needs an agency that believes all over the House .
With other things the Parliament seeks to achieve this objective through its committees in which some of its members work in India particularly .
The review of administrative functions and the examination of various and complex legislative proposals and subordinate legislation require expertise and close scrutiny which are not possible in the Lok Sabha since it involves 545 members .

Position of the Estimates Committee on this
In this case the policy laid down by Parliament by means of statute - wise or by specific resolutions and all other policies which are not so determined have been distinguished .
In regard to the latter cases the सरकार Committee may openly investigate a case which has been settled by the government in the form of a policy by performing its executive duties .
The Committee can examine the functioning of the policy and not the approved policy by the Parliament .
Thus where it is found that the desired results of a particular policy are not coming out and the wastage is a duty of the Estimates Committee to bring out the shortcomings and to bring into consideration the policy of Parliament .
It has 22 members ( 15 from Lok Sabha and 7 from Rajya Sabha .

The Committee on Public Undertakings : The planned economic development for our country necessitated setting up of numerous industrial undertakings agriculture commerce commercial etc. controlled and managed by the Government of India .
Thus a large number of corporations and government companies that are generally called Public Sector Companies हैं have come into existence with huge sums .
Since the moneys invested in them have been taken from the Consolidated Fund of India Lok Sabha is liable to have adequate control over their functions .
For this purpose a Committee on Public Undertakings consisting of 22 members of whom 15 are elected by the Lok Sabha and 7 by the Rajya Sabha .
The Chairman of the committee is appointed by the Speaker from among the members elected from the Lok Sabha .
The functions of the Committee are : reports of the government undertakings as specified in the Rules and reports of the Comptroller and Auditor General if any may be examined and see whether business is run in terms of autonomy and efficiency of public enterprises .
