Parliamentary Museum and Archives India has always accorded maximum importance to parliamentary institutions.
Since the past few years efforts are being made to harness all necessary resources for collecting and preserving for the present and future generations .
A beginning was made in 1976 when the Lok Sabha Secretariat set up a Parliamentary Archives of संसदीय and Films to preserve an authentic and up - to - date pictorial record of the history of its activities and personalities.
A proposal to set up a Parliamentary Museum and Archives was approved by the General Purposes Committee of the Lok Sabha on 1 August 1984 .
The basic purpose of the Parliamentary Museum and Archives is to protect people from history and institutions from the present period relating to the Constitution and Parliament and all the precious records of the past historical documents and objects from time to time and for future generations .
At the current stage of its development it is concentrating on acquisition of comprehensive documents , goods etc . that are available with it on its proper preservation and retaining the selected material .
In due course its idea is to spread information about parliamentary institutions and to promote a proper image of the Parliament by creating interest in their activities and its achievements .

The Legislature is not just a club .

Outside the House members are expected to maintain a standard of conduct consistent with the dignity of their office .

The basic features of democracy are that of sovereignty vests in the people ; they are able to do everything in their own without distinction of religion caste creed colour or woman and without distinction of social background .
In a democracy people are regarded as their masters .
They have an inalienable right to rule themselves or to be ruled by the people they choose .
Democracy also admits that from time immemorial man has been fighting with one another for power or dominance .
Democracy tries to substitute a more civilised manner of struggle .
It presents methods of discussion and persuasion for the methods of armed conflict .
All citizens assembled together in the ancient Indian village republics and the Greek City states and decided the problems of governance .
From the British Commonwealth it became the Commonwealth of nations .
The Commonwealth specifically recognised India ' s position as a sovereign independent republic .
It did not therefore affect the sovereign democratic or republican form of the state .
Social and Economic democracy : Democracy conceived in political terms means that every citizen has the right to vote at a time .
In all democratic elections the principle of ' a man ' s " vote " applied to a vote - is derived from the recognition of the fact that all men have equal rights whether highly educated or illiterate industrialists .
But in the eyes of the framers of our Constitution democracy does not mean merely the right to vote for the people to choose their representatives at the time of political democracy or at the appointed time .
Without social and economic democracy political democracy has no meaning in a poor country like India .
Dr .
According to Ambedkar social and economic democracy is the real purpose and ultimate objective .
He said that parliamentary democracy would be meaningful only when it was geared to achieving the real goal of economic democracy .
Jawaharlal Nehru later expressed his views that democracy was the only means of achieving the goal .
The objective is to provide a good life for each person to meet certain essential economic needs .
The measure in which democracy succeeds in solving economic problems is at the same level successful in the political field .
If economic problems are not solved then the political structure becomes weak and breaks .
It has been clarified by these words of the Preamble that all citizens of the Republic have received " Social Justice " Economic and Political Justice .
Justice means harmony between the mutual interests of individuals between groups of individuals and groups on the one hand and interests of the community on the other .
The most important point in the Preamble is that justice has been given a higher place than the principles of liberty equality and fraternity .
The concept of justice is indeed very wide .
It is not confined to narrow legal justice granted by courts .
Social justice implies that all citizens are treated alike and are not regarded as equal in matters of justice in society because of their status in the matter of birth नागरिकों race caste sex title etc .
Article 15 prohibits discrimination or disability in the matter of access to public places .
The humane conditions of work maternity relief maternity relief promoting economic interests of the deprived groups ; minimum wage banning of forced labour ( articles 23 and 43 ) aims at social justice .
Economic justice is expected to treat the rich and the poor alike and try to bridge the gap between them .
In pursuance of the objective of economic justice Article ; enjoins upon the State to ensure that all citizens have adequate means of livelihood without having the same rights as those of men without caring for equal employment and for the same rights as those of men .
In fact the aim of various other articles ( articles 36 to 51 ) in Part 4 of the Constitution is also to ensure a new social and economic order imbued with justice .
The vision of status and equality of opportunity has been incorporated in our Preamble .
Its legal objectives are social cultural political and economic aspects .
All citizens are equal in the eyes of law and enjoy equal protection of the laws of the country .
All citizens enjoy equal rights to vote without any discrimination and to participate in the process of governance .
Equality in the economic field means that salary for one ' s ability and labour will also be one .
Moreover the exploiters will not exploit one person or another class .
The concept of equality of status and opportunity has been given concrete shape and form in articles 14 to 18 .
The ideals of fraternity justice equality freedom and equality are relevant and meaningful so long as they promote the brotherhood of Indian brotherhood the sons of the same Mother and many other forms of racial brotherhood .
Provisions relating to common citizenship are meant to strengthen the spirit of Indian fraternity and build up a strong Indian brotherhood .
The fundamental rights of all citizens without any discrimination have been guaranteed and the Directive Principles aimed at social and economic equality are also meant to promote affinities .
This separation of religion and politics leads beyond religion and religion freedom of religion equal respect to all religions etc .

Sri Aurobindo ( 1872 - 1950 ) Sri Aurobindo ( Aurobindo Ghose ) was born on 15 August 1872 in Calcutta .
His father पिता Ghose ( 1845 ) dealt with the well - established Ghose family of West Bengal .
When Aurobindo was seven years old his father had taken him and his two elder brother अरविंद इंग्लैंड and Manmohan to England .
His early education took place in an English family .
When he joined the St. Paul ' s School as a researcher he knew Latin and could understand Shakespeare and the romantic poets himself .
He had mastered Goethe Dante and दांते in his native language the French था German इतालवी Italian and Spanish .
At eleven he began writing poetry in Greek Latin and English .
As a secretary to the Indian Majlis Cambridge University he made revolutionary speeches hinting at armed rebellion as the only way to India ' s liberation .
Though he passed the Indian Civil Service examination he did not enter it and returned to India in 1893 with an appointment at the Baroda State Service .
He took thirteen years to reach the post of the Principal in charge of the state College at Baroda .
He learnt Sanskrit Bengali from Marathi बांग्ला Gujarati and spoken बांग्ला the epics the Upanishads and Sanskrit literature and wrote poetry in English drama and drama .
He shifted to Calcutta as the principal of the newly formed National College ( now Jadavpur ) .
Aurobindo directed बंगाल to use the partition of Bengal to increase its activities .
He gave instructions to नेशनलिस्टों for his policy and policy organisation and he launched the famous daily अंग्रेजी अंग्रेजी and joined the English daily of Bipin Chandra Pal .
A series of articles published in the Bande Mataram बंदे published in a series of articles describing the true method of implementation of the nationalist programme of ' Swadeshi ' and ' boycott ' .
In August 1907 Aurobindo was arrested for certain articles published in the Bande Mataram but the charge failed because it could not be proved that he was the editor of that letter .
He was also arrested with 38 other revolutionaries in May 1908 where he spent a year in the form of " रिहाई " before his release .
In jail he had the experience of a self - conscious consciousness and had a vision of Sri Krishna everywhere and there was an assurance of the freedom of India and his release for the welfare of the world .
After his release in May 1909 Aurobindo resumed his mission and wrote articles on the real intention of Indian nationalism in two newly - कर्मयोगी कर्मयोगी कर्मयोगी कर्मयोगी ( English ) and in Bengali .
One evening in February 1910 he received information that his office would be searched and arrested the following day .
He left for Pondicherry on hearing the voice of his conscience and went to Pondicherry where he devoted himself entirely to literature and philosophy .
In his mission he received the co - operation of an enlightened French फ्रांसिसी Paul and his wife ( later known as the Mother ) who came to Pondicherry at the mouth of the First World War .
In 1926 Aurobindo retired into seclusion which he stayed till his death in 1950 .

The period 1928 - 1929 was significant in Indian history as it was the beginning of an organised left - wing movement ( including all economic and political components ) .
The establishment of trade unions enabled the workers to keep their grievances in front of them and to fight for good salary and better working conditions .
Though the Communist Party of India had been active for a long time in India the movement had not been able to achieve anything special .
It was only after 1927 that during 1929 - 29 the communists had made considerable headway in their efforts to build their seats in trade union and labour organisations and found a powerful section of nationalist bourgeoisie .
Even some British citizens were making active contribution to this movement .
Soon the British Government became alarmed and took several legislative and administrative steps to nip the movement .
The most important and repressive measures were the launching of a conspiracy case against prominent leftist workers at Meerut which had greatly influenced the future of the Communist Party of India and the whole communist movement in the country .

The first phase of the Meerut conspiracy case the magistrate enquiry ended on 15 December 1929 after seven months .

The second trial of 1908 is of historical importance because it has a special place in criminal jurisprudence .

Surendra Nath Banerjea was editor of an English letter in which he wrote an editorial article on 28th April 1883 .
This article was based on a report published in the Brahmo Public Opinion stating that a judge of the Calcutta High Court Mr Justice Norris had ordered a Hindu accused to appear before the court .
नौरिस Norris had earlier often made decisions with prejudice against the Hindus in many cases .
The report echoed the sentiments of most of the people in Bengal and Surendranath Banerjee popularly known for his fearlessness and के wrote an article criticising the judge ' s sentiments and not of the High Court . "
The article created a stir not only in Calcutta but also in the whole of India ; it hurt not only the feelings of the Hindus but also the sentiments of the British judiciary particularly the English judges .
The language of the article was और and और .
It was a frontal attack on judiciary and particularly on the member of the High Court .

The circumstances which are in British India are seen in them with great respect the high courts of this Hon’ble court and the other community and I believe that it is the most sincere privilege and honour of all these sections of society .

Thermal power stations produce large quantities of fly ash and disposal is a global problem .
The fly ash is a fine ash produced by burning coal in thermal power stations and accounts for about 80 - 85 per cent of the total ash produced .
There are 66 thermal power stations in India which produce about three to four million tonnes of fly ash per annum .
These are either dried up in gunny bags or converted into slurry ( to stop air pollution ) and this slurry is put into a tank of ash from where it is discharged into a nearby river .
The latest data shows that if the fly ash has been thrown continuously for years it will require over 283 square kilometres of land and will cause serious ecological problems .
Research continues to be carried out all over the world to tap the fly ash to avoid too much water and the problem of land .
